docs.title: FossWiki
docs.text: Everything about FOSS. From what it is, how to use it, to detailed guide on configuration and installation that is beginner-friendly.

docs.title: Contribution
docs.text:
• Submit an issue on the official GitHub Repo for any FOSS you want to add.

  • Even better? Submit a Pull Request. See the guide for pull requests below.

docs.title: Pull Requests
docs.text:
First, fork this repository.

Then, clone it and create a new branch using

git clone git@github.com:<your-username>/fosswiki.git
cd fosswiki
git checkout new-branch

docs.title: For adding a FOSS, or change of documentation
docs.text:
Add/Change the .md file under docs folder, make appropreate changes to mkdocs.yml, then submit a pull request.

GitHub Actions should automatically generate a file under site.

docs.title: For making changes to the config files
docs.text: Change the files, then submit a pull requests.

docs.title: What should not be changed without creating an issue first:
Linux
docs.text:
According to Wikipedia, Linux is a is a generic name for a family of open-source Unix-like operating systems based on the Linux kernel, an operating system kernel first released on September 17, 1991, by Linus Torvalds.

In another word, it is a Unix-like system, its original kernel is made by Linux Torvalds. Fun fact: he also made the version control tool git. Github and Codeberg are two softwares that host Git repositories.

Things to know before deciding to use linux:

  • Distributions, often refered as distros, are different versions of the Linux operating system, each tailored with its own set of features and customization. There are a lot of them. Some populat distributions includes Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, Arch and Gentoo.

  • Commands. There are a lot of linux commands you should be familiar with. You should use those commands inside a terminal. Examples:

  • ls to list all files

  • cd to change the current working directory
  • pwd to show the current working directory
  • cp to copy files
  • mv to move files
  • rm to move files
  • chmod to change file permissions
  • chown to change the file's ownership
  • grep to search text in files
  • cat to show contents of a file
Never run a command that you do not understand. Linux gives you full power to run commands, therefore you should be very careful about what you type.
  • [For Advanced Users] Desktop Enviroments. You will need to manually install on some Linux Distros, such as Arch Linux and Gentoo Linux. However, some Linux Distros allows you to choose a Desktop Enviroment, such as Ubuntu, which offers normal ubuntu and kubuntu.
